questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of a progressively worsening rash on his buttocks for the last week. He cries during diaper changes and is more fussy than usual. Physical examination of the boy shows erythematous papules and plaques in the bilateral inguinal creases, on the scrotum, and in the gluteal cleft. Small areas of maceration are also present. A diagnosis is made, and treatment with topical clotrimazole is initiated. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings from this patient's rash is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae
Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Narrow budding, encapsulated yeast on India ink staining indicates Cryptococcus neoformans infection. Cryptococcus neoformans infection is primarily seen in immunocompromised patients and can cause pneumonia, cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and brain abscesses. Cryptococcus neoformans is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

B) CORRECT:

Candida albicans appears as oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae in skin scrapings of an infection. Candida albicans is part of the normal skin flora, but infection can occur when there is an imbalance that allows local Candida albicans overgrowth. Infants are often affected by Candida mucocutaneous infections in the anogenital region since overgrowth is facilitated by the prolonged damp and warm conditions of a diaper.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.

C) INCORRECT:

Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae (45°) on tissue biopsy indicate Aspergillus fumigatus infection. Aspergillus fumigatus can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, invasive aspergillosis, and infective endocarditis. Although Aspergillus fumigatus can cause irritation of the skin in patients with ABPA, it is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells (captain's wheel) on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection is most often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with acute pneumonia, painful nasopharyngeal ulcerations, and verrucous skin lesions. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

E) INCORRECT:

Broad-based budding yeast on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Blastomyces dermatitidis infection. This patient has a diaper rash and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., pneumonia, flulike symptoms), making a Blastomyces dermatitidis infection highly unlikely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.
questions.hint: This patient has typical signs of a diaper rash due to Candida albicans. It can be treated with a variety of topical antifungal agents such as clotrimazole.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of redness and swelling of the head of his penis for the past 2 days. The mother says that he has constantly been scratching his genital area since yesterday. She has also noticed an unpleasant smell when changing his diaper. One week ago, the boy had a diaper rash that slightly improved with an over-the-counter ointment. He is uncircumcised and has no history of serious illness. The boy's parents, as well as his two older sisters, are well. Immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 75th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the genital area shows erythematous plaques and scattered pustules in the perianal area, inguinal creases, and on the glans penis and foreskin as well as edema of the glans penis. A white, curd-like discharge appears from under the foreskin. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. In addition to counseling on proper genital hygiene, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

White curd-like discharge from under the foreskin, the presence of scattered satellite pustules, the involvement of skin folds (inguinal creases), and persistent diaper dermatitis (> 3 days) strongly suggest fungal balanoposthitis as a result of candidal superinfection of diaper dermatitis. In infants, fungal balanoposthitis in association with candida diaper dermatitis is usually a clinical diagnosis and empiric topical antifungal agents (e.g., clotrimazole) are indicated to treat this local mucocutaneous dermatophyte infection. In addition, barrier ointments should be applied 2–3 times daily until resolution is achieved. Further measures to control the local inflammation include sitz baths and avoidance of irritants (e.g., soap, talc powder), as well as counseling on genital hygiene.

In prepubertal patients that have balanoposthitis with urethral discharge, diagnostic workup for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) is indicated and, if STIs are confirmed, evaluation for sexual abuse should follow.
Image Description:

There is diffuse dark erythema with confluent papules, scaling, and satellite lesions of the perianal and infraumbilical region. Skin folds are involved.

These findings suggest Candida diaper dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is indicated in the case of bacterial balanoposthitis due to group A Streptococci (GAS). Patients with GAS balanoposthitis typically have a history of recent or ongoing GAS infection (e.g., tonsillopharyngitis, perianal streptococcal dermatitis) or contact with an infected individual (e.g., family member). Perianal streptococcal dermatitis typically manifests with bright red erythema most prominent in the perianal area, rather than with widespread pustules and plaques extending to the inguinal creases. Satellite pustules and a curd-like discharge from under the foreskin suggest a different etiology of balanoposthitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is indicated in genital herpes simplex virus infection, which can cause balanoposthitis. Genital herpes is classically associated with painful and pruritic vesicles in the anogenital region, rather than plaques and satellite pustules. Moreover, a white curd-like discharge would not be expected. Genital herpes is uncommon in toddlers and would warrant evaluation for sexual abuse.

D) INCORRECT:

Circumcision (or alternatively preputioplasty) is a treatment option for patients with balanoposthitis that is recurrent or fails conservative treatment because the foreskin predisposes to future infections. This patient has neither of these indications, so another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone can be used in the treatment of irritant balanoposthitis. The presence of satellite pustules and white curd-like discharge from under the foreskin strongly suggest a different, infectious cause of balanoposthitis, for which topical corticosteroids are contraindicated.
questions.hint: Erythema and edema of both the glans penis and the foreskin indicate balanoposthitis. This patient's history of a pruritic malodorous diaper rash (diaper dermatitis) for one week and the white curd-like discharge suggest a specific etiology.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old boy is evaluated for a rash in his diaper area that has been worsening for the past 7 days.
Examination reveals a prominent, bright-red, well-demarcated, slightly scaly rash involving the buttocks, genitals, inguinal folds, lower abdomen, and thighs. The periphery is marked by slightly scaly papules and pustules (figure).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in managing this child’s rash?

choices.text: Recommend a topical barrier cream alone
Recommend a topical ointment containing bacitracin-neomycin-polymyxin B

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Barrier creams are important and should be used in conjunction with a topical antifungal for the treatment of candidal dermatitis in order to protect the skin from irritation. Barrier creams alone, however, will not treat the underlying candidal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Low-potency topical glucocorticoids, such as 1% hydrocortisone ointment, are often used in conjunction with antifungal creams if there is very severe underlying inflammation that is impeding the healing of the rash. However, glucocorticoids should not be used as the sole treatment, and superpotent topical glucocorticoids, such as clobetasol, should be avoided in the diaper area. Combination high-potency topical glucocorticoids mixed with a topical antifungal are also not recommended for use in the diaper area because of possible adverse effects from the high-potency topical glucocorticoid.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibacterial agents, such as mupirocin and bacitracin-neomycin-polymyxin B, are not effective against fungi, including Candida species, and have no role in the treatment of candidal diaper rash.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibacterial agents, such as mupirocin and bacitracin-neomycin-polymyxin B, are not effective against fungi, including Candida species, and have no role in the treatment of candidal diaper rash.

E) CORRECT:

Diaper dermatitis is a common condition in which the skin under the diaper becomes red. Classic (irritant) diaper dermatitis is multifactorial but is caused primarily by prolonged contact of the skin with moisture in the diaper from urine, digestive enzymes, and bile salts. It is characterized by a dry, erythematous rash that spares the creases of the thighs and folds of the skin because the irritating moisture mixture is unable to get to the skin protected by these creases and folds. In contrast, candidal diaper dermatitis, as in this case, tends to involve the inguinal folds and to feature discrete inflammatory papules and pustules (so-called satellite lesions).

Candidal diaper dermatitis is a fungal infection most commonly caused by Candida albicans, which thrives in warm, moist environments. Candidal dermatitis typically develops as a superinfection 3 to 4 days after the onset of irritant diaper dermatitis. The gold standard for diagnosis is the appearance of budding yeast with pseudohyphae on potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation; however, in primary care settings, the diagnosis is often made clinically.

The first-line treatment for isolated candidal diaper dermatitis is a topical antifungal agent, such as nystatin or clotrimazole.

Key learning point: The appropriate treatment for candidal diaper dermatitis is a topical antifungal agent, such as nystatin.

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection is most often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with acute pneumonia, painful nasopharyngeal ulcerations, and verrucous skin lesions. Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

Broad-based budding yeast on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Blastomyces dermatitidis infection. This patient has a diaper rash and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., pneumonia, flulike symptoms), making a Blastomyces dermatitidis infection highly unlikely.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-month-old boy brought to your clinic by his father because of a progressively worsening rash on his buttocks over the past week. The father reports that the infant cries during diaper changes and is more fussy than usual. On examination, there are erythematous papules and plaques in the bilateral inguinal creases, on the scrotum, and in the gluteal cleft, with small areas of maceration. You diagnose the condition and start treatment with topical clotrimazole. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings from this rash is most likely to show which one of the following findings?

choices.text: Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae.
Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae (45°) on tissue biopsy indicate Aspergillus fumigatus infection. Aspergillus fumigatus can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, invasive aspergillosis, and infective endocarditis. Although Aspergillus fumigatus can cause irritation of the skin in patients with ABPA, it is not associated with diaper rash.

Broad-based budding yeast on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Blastomyces dermatitidis infection. This patient has a diaper rash and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., pneumonia, flulike symptoms), making a Blastomyces dermatitidis infection highly unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Narrow budding, encapsulated yeast on India ink staining indicates Cryptococcus neoformans infection. Cryptococcus neoformans infection is primarily seen in immunocompromised patients and can cause pneumonia, cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and brain abscesses. Cryptococcus neoformans is not associated with diaper rash.

D) INCORRECT:

Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells (captain's wheel) on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection is most often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with acute pneumonia, painful nasopharyngeal ulcerations, and verrucous skin lesions. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is not associated with diaper rash.

Candida albicans appears as oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae in skin scrapings of an infection. Candida albicans is part of the normal skin flora, but infection can occur when there is an imbalance that allows local Candida albicans overgrowth. Infants are often affected by Candida mucocutaneous infections in the anogenital region since overgrowth is facilitated by the prolonged damp and warm conditions of a diaper.

Key learning point: Candida albicans diaper rash is characterized microscopically by oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae on skin scrapings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

questions.text: A 10-month-old male infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents with a 2-day history of fussiness and crying during diaper changes. The parents report using a new brand of scented wipes for the past week. Examination findings are shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Bacterial culture of the affected area
Frequent diaper changes and barrier cream

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patch testing is used for diagnostic uncertainty in suspected allergic contact dermatitis. The rash in allergic contact dermatitis typically involves the skin folds and has distinct borders that correspond to exposure sites. However, this patient's rash spares the skin folds, which is consistent with irritant rather than allergic contact dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

While low-potency topical corticosteroids like hydrocortisone may be considered for inflammation, another step is the cornerstone of management and should be initiated first. Corticosteroids alone do not address the underlying cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical antifungals are indicated for candidal diaper dermatitis, which typically involves skin folds and has satellite lesions. This patient's rash spares the inguinal folds and is limited to diaper-contact areas, making irritant contact dermatitis more likely than candidal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacterial cultures are reserved for severe bacterial infections or those that do not respond to empiric antibiotics. This patient's clinical presentation is inconsistent with bacterial infection.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Erythema on convex surfaces with sparing of the skin folds is consistent with irritant diaper dermatitis. Diaper hygiene is the cornerstone of management for irritant diaper dermatitis. This approach includes frequent diaper changes and barrier emollients containing zinc oxide according to the ABCDE criteria.
